item.title: Polynomial approximations without Taylor's theorem
item.description: Taylor’s theorem for constructing a polynomial approximation to a function has two parts: Constructing a polynomial whose derivatives match those of the function at the center point, and Constructing a remainder (error) term for the difference between the function and the approximating polynomial. Part 1 requires taking derivatives of the function, and part 2 requires using the mean value theorem (Lagrange and Cauchy forms of the remainder) or an integral.
